On Oct 3, 2007, at 8:05 PM, Kenneth Stanley wrote:

> So I think that is the main pricing question: For $10,000, if you
> are efficient, you can buy maybe a 20-core cluster, which in effect
> is a 10x speedup from a regular 2-core CPU. So a 20x speedup sounds
> economical if it is genuine.

With ASICs, I think the gain could be considerably more, if, as you  
said, the hardware actually speeds up the most expensive part of NEAT.

> specific to NEAT. In fact, in many domains, it is task the domain
> simulation itself that takes the vast majority of CPU

I agree..  Though, maybe this hardware is going to be dedicated to n- 
dimensional time-series modeling and prediction?  Someone else  
mentioned it looked like it was probably meant for financial  
applications.  In the case of a fixed-time series (historical stock  
prices, etc.), the speedup may be tremendous.

But I'm with you Ken, for any problem requiring simulation, this  
isn't going to be worth $10k.
--
Stephen Waits
steve@...
http://swaits.com/



--Apple-Mail-5-600711476
